title: Julie Hermann: My job to support Rutgers football, Kyle Flood
text:
Julie Hermann: My job to support Rutgers football, Kyle Flood Ryan Dunleavy , @rydunleavy 10:05 a.m. EDT October 26, 2015 Rutgers athletic director Julie Hermann speaks Saturday at the groundbreaking for the new baseball and softball training facility. (Photo: Jason Towlen/Staff Photographer) 19 CONNECT 6 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
PISCATAWAY - The irony to the nearby shovels, hard hats and mounds of freshly dug dirt was that Rutgers still hasn't completely buried the controversy surrounding its flagship athletics program. 
Athletics director Julie Hermann celebrated the most significant day of her 29-month tenure Saturday as she and other school officials held a groundbreaking ceremony for the fully privately fundraised $3.3 million Fred Hill Training Complex for the baseball and softball programs. 
But Rutgers football, which is under broad investigation by school-hired outside counsel to determine if it has violated any NCAA rules , still was a topic broached during a rare interview with beat reporters. 
"I have one job every day and that is (to) support my student-athletes, that is to support my coaches," Hermann told Gannett New Jersey. "I support Kyle and my football team every day and we’re totally focused on it." Rutgers holds groundbreaking for new baseball, softball facility 
As was the case with past Rutgers athletic directors, it is Hermann's policy not to comment on coaching performances in-season. 
Of course, this isn't the typical season, with Flood having served a three-game suspension handed out by Rutgers president Robert Barchi for his impermissible contact with a faculty member. 
Seven players have been arrested -- six of whom were dismissed from the program and one of whom had his charge dismissed -- since Sept. 3. 
One of those former players, Lloyd Terry, allegedly told police that he failed multiple drug tests while a member of the team, shining a spotlight on Rutgers athletics drug policy , especially the difference in penalties for football players and other student-athletes . 
So the significance of changing the narrative with a groundbreaking -- Rutgers hasn't added a new athletics facility to the campus map since 1987 -- wasn't lost on Hermann. Rutgers football rewind: Ohio State rolls to 49-7 win 
"We had a lot of momentum coming into the summer," Hermann said. "And it’s time to build the momentum back and get going. We’ve got great opportunities in the Big Ten and we’ve got supporters willing to do that. We’re focused on that going forward." 
Rutgers Board of Governors approved a new long-term wide-ranging facilities plan in June and then Rutgers athletics alums Carli Lloyd and Todd Frazier captured the nation's attention with standout performances in the Women's World Cup and the Major League Baseball Home Run Derby, respectively.
